Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2008 10:32PM - edited Feb 24, 2008 10:34PM by Miss_Lolli Red, from what I've read and what I feel (recently completed radiation) I KNOW that you are not alone. I also hear, from survivors, and have to trust that this will get better. There are lots of places you can get free counseling and/or join support groups. If you feel that this fear is interfering with you living your life, you should definitely contact someone. I know I can find you some links (american cancer society etc.) if you feel you need more support than what this board and friends/family can provide. Let me know.. If you are involved in a local church I'm sure they could steer you as well. Some women don't feel that support groups are right for them, but have found anti-depressants to be helpful at this difficult time, I'm sure your onc could help you with that. I truly believe that the period of adjustment after treatment may be the roughest part for me. When you're actively treating you're focused on something....fighting....often afterwards we wonder, "now what"? In the mean time, here is a link from this site on dealing with cancer fears. If you scroll down there's a few topics I found helpful. http://www.breastcancer.org/community/fears/index.jsp

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 05:55PM Miss_Lolli wrote: I also ate many "favorite things" during chemo and didn't develop aversions. Although like many, I did totally lose my sweet tooth and found things tasted very salty to me as well. I basically found one or two things that tasted good to me and stuck with them. (If I remember right it was homemade chicken noodle soup with some veggies, string cheese and canned fruits). I can say that I didn't enjoy food enough to keep eating once I had eaten enough to make the hunger go away, so I ended up having many "snacks" throughout the day. My weight went down about ten pounds, I'd say the low end of what it should be, but they say that's a very healthy way to eat anyway. Supposedly, if you let your tummy get empty that's when it gets most upset. I will say my main tip is to drink flat ginger ale or hot tea with ginger. It settled my tummy enough to make me feel a bit hungry.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 04:56AM Miss_Lolli wrote: Trisha...let me just say I totally understand and I'm sorry for what you're going through. I too thought I wouldn't need chemo, and was absoloutely terrified by the thought. When my oncologist explained how much it would cut my chance of recurrance and explained that I could "opt out" if I ever felt like I just couldn't handle it (yes I was that apprehenesive) I decided to go ahead. It's not even close to as horrible as you imagine, I can almost guarantee. Yes, I felt crappy (kind of like pregnant with a hint of flu) for about six days the first treatment, but they really have so many good drugs these days, and have come such a long way. Almost any complaint you have with side-effects can be helped. I had my second treatment last Friday, and have been lucky enough, this time, to have no problem with nausea at all.....only some tiredness....go figure. So, it can be different for everyone, or individual each time. The actual infusion is nothing at all. You sit there and get an IV and for all I could tell, they might have been giving me saline water. I don't have a port because I'm only receiving four treatments, and didn't want another small surgery, but after eight tries to get a good vein last time, if I had more, I'd rethink that decision too. lol  Please come back and let us know how you are, and if you have any more questions. This site and the girls in the October thread are so incredibly helpful. Alishar you did it! And the wig looks fab!! I'm so sorry about your sister honey. It brings tears to my eyes that this disease causes so much tragic loss. That's why we're gonna kick it's arse...the b(*&rd! Hugs n love all.... Lolli

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2007 05:29PM Miss_Lolli wrote: Sorry Varasri, your post was not there when I started typing, so I did not mean to ignore. There is a section on this site that explains in detail what your pathology report means. However, I would mostly advise you this. Write down every question you can think of between now and your next meeting with your oncologist and have him explain things to you until you feel satisfied that you know everything you need and want to know.  But the one thing I would say you should ignore is statistics. You are not a number but a person...and none of these "percentages" matter when it comes to our lives. If only one person out of 100 has a good prognosis you could be that one, but who wants to start out knowing the odds are against us? I'm not saying they are against you at all of course, as there were some things in your report worded differently than mine (probably because of the difference in country), so I don't quite understand everything in your post. I do know one thing....if your doctor isn't willing to talk to you until you understand, then you need to talk to another one and another until you find one who will. The good news is, it sounds like they got all the tumor out with clear margins, and the fact that you're estrogen positive is also good, in that there is medicine they can give you for years after your chemo to help prevent recurrance. I guess we've all had moments we've feared for our lives...it's like being slapped in the face with your own mortality,and it's scary. But the good news, they've made incredible strides in the past ten years. They've come so far, and we have an amazing amount of options for treatment. If I were you, I'd plan on being at your beautiful daughter's graduation. Please come back often and let us know how you're doing.

Posts.Content: May 18, 2008 02:52AM Miss_Lolli wrote: Evy, SO sorry I missed your post. I'm really sad that you have to deal with more. And I will pray soooo very hard that you will have many babies when this is all over. You will be a wonderful mommy. Well ladies, yesterday was the warmest day since last Oct. 7th!!! FINALLY we have spring and it's just glorious here. No bugs and mosquitos out yet since it's been so cold. We had a bonfire last night and tonight I'm supposed to go to the drive-in. So I'm soaking it up while it lasts. lol I want to share some good news with my sisters. You probably remember last Jan. when my sister got very sick with pneumonia and very low oxygen levels supposedly caused by a sleep disorder and other health issues. She was in the ICU and almost didn't make it through the first night, and has been on oxygen every since. They told her she may never be free of it. WELL...she quit smoking, lost quite a bit of weight, and worked very very hard exercising and doing pulmonary rehab and this week she got to get rid of her oxygen for good!!!!!!! yay yay yay!  The doctor told her it was nothing short of miraculous and her oxygen levels are almost that of someone who'd never even had supplemental oxygen!!! OMG we were just bawling and I'm so proud of her! I didn't say much about it, because they never really knew what was going on besides that she was very sick. But, just having all your love and support helped me tremendously. Thank you!

Posts.Content: May 31, 2008 04:02PM Miss_Lolli wrote: LOL! No wonder she was such a HUGE star. Karen, I hear ya on the soy. I had that same rant somewhere on this site already too. It's next to impossible to avoid it entirely. I'm down to settling for things where it's not in one of the first few listed ingredients, if at all. If I feel I must eat something with high content such as soy sauce, it's a rare treat. I just try to hope that the tamoxifen is doing it's job and they haven't underplayed the role soy has in our cancer. Right now it seems they don't know exactly to what extent it is bad for us. I don't know...I've done so much research and get so many conflicting theories, just like everything else regarding nutrition. Sue and Ulla, I think the website you may be looking for is adjuvantonline? It's not so much that you plug in what you've done for treatment, but you enter info from your pathology and it gives you tx recommendations along with percentages regarding prognosis. You have to sign in as a doctor (I just used false info) but my own onc even said I can go in there and "play around" at home to see what I find. It's supposed to be a diagnostic aid for oncs, but I'll be it's used my just as many curious patients. Have a lovely weekend sisters! Big hugs and lotsa love.....

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2007 02:28PM Miss_Lolli wrote: Kristina...plugged up, Xanaxed, or any which way, you always crack me up. Love your spirit, and hope you feel better soon. Doritoes yum! As you said, the list of things I presently consider better than sex grows with each passing year. And the list has gotten crazily larger since chemo...never dreamed "food that tastes like food" or "a good number two" would be on that list though. ;-)  Linda....welcome, that's quite a story! Regarding your question...I'm only one treatment into it too, but my oncology nurse seems to think that nothing should get worse or be cumulative except for the fatigue. I hope she's right, but I'm not going to count on it.  I'm guessing if you had an easy time the first time, it won't get too bad for you if you do end up having se's. Myself, I'm hoping to do better the second time because I plan on starting the first day of treatment with Colace and antacid right off. I honestly think I wouldn't have felt badly (beyond unbelievably tired) if it wasn't for those miserable se's. I'd never dealt with either of those problems in my life, and I think I didn't even realize what was making me feel badly! Are you every two or three weeks for your tx? Funny, I was totally wiped out a few days after my treatment like you said also. I wondered if it coincided with the end of your steroids? Paxton brought that up on the chemo tip thread and said that was her experience, so it's got me wondering. Makes some sense too.... Anyone else feel like you crash when your steroids are gone? Of course I'm not going to stop taking anything w/o talking to the onc, but it's worth asking about. I felt like I could hardly move the two days after my prescription was done....hmmmm....

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 06:32AM - edited Nov 8, 2007 07:26AM by Miss_Lolli Okay..I remembered something about that number so I had to look it up on my own report.  The 9 that Trisha is referring to is a "Nottingham score", and that is graded  up to a 9. It is on the pathology report next to the exact dx (i.e. IDC etc) for example it says *nottingham grade: II of III, nottingham score: 5 of 9*. At least that's how it looked on my report. It was below the her 2 section under surgical panel. Hope this helps....

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2007 04:47PM Miss_Lolli wrote: OH hotmedic..I hope you meant what you said about "WAS having" suicidal thoughts...It sounds to me like you realize that for you that's ridiculous, but PLEASE remember if you start to have them again, it's not real, normal, rational thoughts but your brain chemistry totally out of whack and not being realistic. Being a nurse I'm sure you understand all that anyway but just try to focus on others and how much they love and need you if you ever start thinking like that again. I know it's hard, and I've been bored literally to tears many times...so I sympathize truly.  I have had more crying jags from being bored than anything else since dx. But it always got better and it always turned out to be my emotions and hormones more than anything. I go from reading to tv to puzzles to the computer and back again. I've even consider xmas crafts (if you knew my patience level you'd cringe at the possibility of what I would turn out lol). It's even been too cold for me to walk much this week. And if all else fails, and you still feel that down, just pm me (private message) with your phone number and I'll call you. Heck, I've got nothing but time and am rarely too busy for a phone chat. I just try to focus on a some month in the future when things will be a bit more "normal" or if that seems too overwhelming, then I just focus on holding it together just for today. Whatever you need to get through. This winter will suck big-time, but time will march on, and soon you'll be back to feeling productive and needed again. I think it's so important to us women and one of the things that's so hard. I'm sorry you're having such a bad time, and I'll say an extra prayer for you. Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2007 09:03AM Miss_Lolli wrote: Karen and Karyll, I just have to say that you both are an inspiration. The positive attitudes, openness....so willing to share of yourself to help others. I'm glad you are able to concentrate on your obviously beautiful souls and huge hearts. The kind of attitude you have is what I'm striving for, but I feel so far away from where you are. I'll keep striving. I always used to see the positive in things and laugh a lot....I guess at this time it's just a lot harder and may take me some time and effort to get there. Hotmedic...all I can say is, if you were "hot" before treatment, you will be once again. So no need to mourn your lost beauty. It's just on a little vacation, and probably not as far away as you think. It will be back. We're all bound to look a little tired and sick with what we're going through, but it's temporary, and I'm guessing more than anything, we're our own worst critic. Ulla....I don't have much good advice for you, as I am not lucky enough to have someone like you have. I will guess that what you're feeling has more to do with how you're feeling inside than how you look outside. You are very pretty and looking at your most recent picture, you look better during chemo than most people look normally. lol  I do sympathize, and can't say I understand what it means to lose a breast, but I will just say you have a gorgeous face and your confidence will come back, I'm sure of it. You will enjoy things again. You have been through SO much, just give yourself time to adjust to everything. You're thinking some very deep thoughts, but in my opinion (sorry) men are pretty simple. He loved you before all this, and he still does. He obviously doesn't see the changes as being drastic enough to change his feelings, and is obviously wise enough to know that the moods you are having are only temporary, and he'll have "his Ulla" back soon. Believe me, I do have doubts about this myself sometimes.....but then I go and read chemo threads from years past, and I see that life does get back to normal for women who have been where we are, and are now months and years out of chemo. True we may never TOTALLY be the same, we've lost our innocence and been slapped in the face with our own mortality, BUT I'm hoping in the future that fragility will be replaced with a deeper appreciation of life. By the way...what you have to offer your husband is love and a lifetime of togetherness, trust and faithfulness. It is okay to doubt how you would handle things in his place. It's natural, and has to do with your depression. But no...you are not a bad person. Just a confused and scared one who needs time to heal. Please don't be hard on yourself. Karen R. Hi girlfriend! I feel blessed to have "met" you too. Hope your holiday season is special and filled with love. Nicki, Happy New Year and hope you're well. Natalie...I rarely got a good night's sleep throughout my whole chemo regimen. Even if I could have slept through the night my bladder wouldn't have let me. Had to stay hydrated to make sure those IV's went smoothly. lol  Make sure to let them know about your finger tips. Sometimes, they change or decrease tx right away to try to ensure that neuropathy is temporary.

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2007 08:11PM - edited Oct 31, 2007 08:27PM by Miss_Lolli Well....my name isn't Karen (heh heh), but I did start chemo in October, so this is my group.  Of course my internet went down the minute I got home from my first chemo, so I haven't been able to post and just got to finish catching up with y'all now. I just want to say that you have all made me laugh, cry, worry, rejoice and be brave at times when that wasn't easy...you're witty, wonderful, and real....so if I MUST join a chemo group I am honored to be a part of this one. Your words of wisdom definitely kept me from freaking out my first time in "the chair". lol I'll try not to ramble too much in introducing myself.....I have two amazing wonderful people I was lucky enough to raise, my son is 18 and the kindest hearted, sweetest person I know, my girl is 20, my best friend and doing amazing in college, shooting for a physician assistant or nurse practitioner. I'm 44 and my name is Lori, although my dear Grandpa rarely called me anything but "lolli" (hence the screen name), and my sister always adds the lil in front. My job is not a desk one, so I'm on leave until after the holidays...am lucky enough to share a house with my big sis and her hubby, so she won't kick me out for not having any money. My tx is 4 dd A/C every two weeks.....my second infusion will be this coming Friday. I felt pretty poorly for six days after my first one, but I hope I have learned some things that may help the next time. Nothing was too severe, it just seemed to wear on me with each day. The October girls seem to be doing very well...so I'm thankful and happy for that. (Ulla, praying for you to find some answers and have an easier time of it next treatment). You've all had some wonderful advice that has helped, the only thing I can add is that I'm in love with ginger.....some peach ginger tea saved my life and I drink a lot of flat ginger ale and munch on some ginger snaps when I feel like a sweet. The stuff is a miracle for upset tummies. Also, I noticed some talked about their hair hurting when it was coming out. I did see on another thread that some women had used the lint brushes with the sticky tape to get rid of the hair stubbles on their head, that seemed to bring some relief from the irritating feeling. I'm sorry that in the middle of the night I can't remember individual schedules...but I do remember that "Mrs." starts chemo today. Good vibes and prayers sent your way today hon. All I can say is...even though I've whined about my se's, it still wasn't even close to as bad as my wild imaginings. The actual infusion was NOTHING and I felt very good and energetic for hours afterwards....although like someone said....I almost felt like I had taken something illegal...I was a bit hyper and talked non-stop for a couple of hours. Yeah...I know...not too much diff than the usual as you can see. ;)  I'm blaming it on the steroids. lol Okay....now that I have the picture in my head of us all answering our doors tonight hatless and shirtless I'm going to be laughing while I'm trying to sleep now....my dog will think I'm nuts. lol  But thanks for giving me pleasant thoughts to drift off on....I think we all need that more often. I have my second treatment this Friday and my best friend is coming to chop my hair off on Thursday, so I'll try to check in at least once before then, and see how it's going for everyone. Peace and be well.....

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2008 11:26AM - edited Feb 25, 2008 11:32AM by Miss_Lolli Hey Ulla...as promised earlier...here's a link with some info about supplements that you were asking about...... I'm just starting to wade through tons of things and so much of it seems to be personal choice or opinion (unfortunately, there's not much funding for research on the benefits of herbs/natural supplements because there's no big money to be made by anyone). I would make sure you're getting enough calcium for your bones and taking it with vitamin D  and magnesium, which will help you absorb the calcium. As for me, if I eat enough calories to get all the vitamins I need in a day I would be huge! So, I take a good multi-vitamin. I'm just too short with a too slow metabolism (too many years of unhealthy dieting) to take in all that food. I now feel like I am at a perfectly healthy weight and want to stay that way. I have some herbs and supplements I'm considering. You may want to look at the alternative/complimentary medicine thread. Tons of good info there about diet etc. http://www.breastcancer.org/tips/nutrition/ask_expert/2007_07/question_01.jsp

Posts.Content: May 8, 2008 10:36AM Miss_Lolli wrote: Oh boy Ulla...just what you did NOT need right now. After keeping it from them all this time there probably couldn't have been a worse day for your family to find out! Did you get your parents calmed down? Now that it's out in the open do you feel the slightest sense of relief? I know it's hard to reassure everyone else that you are going to be just fine, when you're feeling the way you were. I'm sure waiting until Monday is no big deal at all...or even waiting until your hubby is home and giving yourself some time to think. I know I didn't start taking my tamoxifen immediately after radiation. We wanted to make sure that if I had se's I would know which it came from. So, just try to enjoy some treatment-free time knowing that taking a few days off is no big deal in the grand scheme of things. You may even be one of those people who, if you decide to take it, have to work your way gradually up to your dose. As always, keep us posted and keep talking things out with us. It helps for sure.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 02:24PM Miss_Lolli wrote: Karen, what in interesting revelation you had! Even if it is an impossible idea, I totally understand thinking something like that too.  It is so amazing what we dredge up from our subconcious sometimes. Seems like this could be helpful, you figuring out that irrational fear. So not "nitwitty"...... we all have them. You're just in touch enough to figure it out. Also, I think you're very right on and your two cents is worth way more. I did some thinking too and I think I was feeling that if he tries to brush the whole conversation off, or shows signs that he's uncomfortable, I would have a hard time with that. I suppose I could examine it more deeply and figure out why, but it seems secondary. (Maybe I would think it is a sign of weakness or that he doesn't love me enough?) That's silly, and I know it.   Like you said, I just need to keep in mind that he loves me, and we're not perfect. I should understand that he would be nervous about hurting me, and that my scars would bother him because it was a sign of my illness. To think that months after radiation, I would just like to pretend this "whole thing" doesn't exist, is just not going to happen. Obviously, every time he touches me we both think about it. I'm sure he has to stop for a second to figure out which one he doesn't have to be careful with, which in turns reminds me that he has to be careful. UGH....I didn't realize I had such an issue with this! I guess next weekend I'll just lay it out there, and hope that makes things better for me. I really think I'm the one with the problem. It's just so funny how we've talked about the emotional aspect of this in depth, but the physical...nada...just pretended like business as usual. Anyway, thanks so much again for the advice. I hope I didn't make anyone uncomfortable, or give TMI, it just really hit me the other day that I left this conversation go for so long I didn't know how to bring it up. I should have just done it right off. Happy Memorial Day. My prayers and thanks to anyone who have loved ones serving our country, or are doing so themselves. Thank you!

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2008 02:23AM Miss_Lolli wrote: Mommy...I just wanted to let you know that I found a lump when I was exactly your age. It turned out to be nothing. And also had nothing to do with the fact that over twenty years later I did end up with cancer (it was the opposite side of the lump I had at your age). It was quite noticable and felt huge to me, but turned out to be nothing. I don't want to misquote a number, but I do know that a very large percentage of lumps turn out to be benign tissue or cysts. There's no way you won't worry, but try to believe in your husbands words and stay positive. Also remember you ARE strong. You faced up to it, and are seeking out medical help. You immediately came here for answers. That is a great sign of strength and maturity. I wish you well. Please let us know when you're going in again so we can send you extra positive vibes on that day. Cathyamom, I'll be thinking of you Wed.

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 06:46AM Miss_Lolli wrote: Welcome to Lori G and Parsnip. I too am sorry you have to be here, but so glad you found us. I truly think having this place to come to has made everything more tolerable, just knowing I have some wonderful people to share with who understand. I am HUGE on the Biotene program as well as ice during infusion. I bought the biggest bottle of the mouthwash I could find and rinse every time I eat, and brush with the toothpaste as often as I can stand it..even though it's not delicious, it keeps my mouth moist. I got mine at Walgreens, but I've heard Target's have them or maybe for those of you that have Walmart's I think they might as well. One thing I have heard someone who already had mouth sores mention, she broke open vitamin D capsules and applied directly to sores for immediate relief...but of course please ask you onc. Also, have you heard of the "magic mouthwash" you can get a script from your dentist for? Supposed to help so much, I believe a mix of benadryl, antacid, and I think lidocaine? Anyway, a couple things I hope might help you. So sad how many of us have lost our mothers. Especially, when it's not old age, but diseases that affect their quality of life...how very hard. Mine had emphysema... I too think of her daily. It was amazing to me how many months it took for me to stop reaching for the phone daily to tell her something funny, or just to hear her reassuring voice. But on a very wonderful note...she lives many years beyond expected and I got to live with her for about five years before she insisted on going into a nursing home right near the end. I got to know her as a friend as well as a mother at that time, and I thank god for that. Day 16 must be the magic number...I'm having some slight shedding. :(  Ah well....at least I have reason to be glad I went ahead with the crew cut. lol It was kinda fun while it lasted. Kristina...I know that tx 2 was tough, but I have to say something about that. My # 1 was really rough right from the first night...luckily for everyone I hadn't signed on to be able to whine yet...but I had six days of just feeling like a limp dish rag, didn't want to eat and couldn't taste anything. Now mind you it was "doable" but just more-so made me apprehensive about the next one being worse ya know? Well tx number two was Friday and besides some sleepiness from short sleep sessions (steroids) I feel very near 100%!! Nothing has really been tasting or smelling bad!  Pretty much like I felt the week before my last infusion. So, I know people who've had good luck hope they'll all be the same (I hope that for them too), I'm just amazed that my two have been exactly opposite. I just know that is going to happen to you too. I haven't really changed my meds (I did add one extra "as needed" in between doses during the day, and one ativan for the first few overnights which were the worst for me), but mostly the only difference is some automatic antacid the first few days. So....I'm saying extra loud prayers for you between now and #3. Don't forget something ginger. Sheesh I think that shoulda been my screen name the way I love that stuff. lol Cheryl....rest rest rest! I found if I push when I'm too tired it can go downhill fast. Take care. Debbie, thank you for the well-wishes back...I hope it continues too, I'm just so thankful. I hope your sons illness is totally non-contagious, we don't need any extra things to deal with do we? Keep us posted. ULLA, please check in when you can. I hope you're just feeling so good finally, and enjoying some time with hubby now, and just got busy. We do worry though. I have a poll.....how many of us are 44 in here? Seems like I've read this number a lot! I only have a few months to change numbers but I'm holding fast. heh heh Well..the Vikings are starting to come to life, I'd better go cheer them on. :D Hugs lovely October sweeties!

I just got my third bottle, so I'm hoping that's long enough to know. At first I got mild hot flashes at night, and occasional bits of dizziness when I'd flip over during the night (it would last about a second). But even those seem to be less and less. They may never go completely, but nothing I can't deal with very easily. Ulla, I'm SO very happy you can go visit Erik! I knew something was up when you hadn't mentioned him, but now just may not be the right time for any kind of changes. Or at least as far as your hubby is concerned. Men are just very competitive in nature, and while it may not be rational, and is somewhat silly, I can also sympathize with him a bit. He wants to be selfish with your love right now and have it all to himself. As time goes on and on, he will feel more comfortable that you're not going anywhere. Linda, I had a long-time (15 year) friend who pulled away emotionally as well....promised to fix my Jeep and then I didn't see him for six months while I'm off work and going through treatment. He told me I had to call him, because he didn't ever want to wake me, as sleep is so important. I think he didn't want to chance catching me not up to par. He still doesn't want me to talk about my cancer experience (he says "well it's over and now you can just forget about it") HAH that's a joke. But Linda, thank you, you just helped me to see that it was most likely because he felt helpless. He was like a big brother, and always "fixed" whatever was wrong, so that would explain that. I've never let him know that I felt so betrayed, now maybe I can let go of the tiny bit of anger I felt. Although I doubt we'll ever be as close. A TON of people that I didn't expect to, came through for me and were such great emotional support, and I can say that no one else really let me down, so I feel VERY blessed. I know a lot of relationships can get strained from such trauma. When I saw how a couple of my life-long friends were affected, I was worried they may not make it through this, more than I was worried about myself. lol   I think as I look healthier and stronger (i.e. more hair lol) they can maybe let it go a bit. But knowing how I felt about my sister, and how that was harder for me than my own diagnosis, I do empathize. It is so very hard to see someone you love struggle with health issues. I know I've rambled so much already, but this brings to mind another question. My boyfriend (the one I got back together with in March after he was such an incredible friend to me during tx and before), has never mentioned my surgery or the fact that my body is different than the first time we dated. Now honestly, my surgeon was terrific, so it's pretty hard to notice anything different, but I do have a small scar/tiny dent and a bit bigger scar with a tiny bit of swelling where the node surgery was. He basically never touches my surgery area, just occasionally the "other one". We are very open with each other, but that's just one subject neither of us has broached. I have thanked him for being there when I expected him to run the other way (after all I had been trying to "get rid" of him for three years and telling him to move on anyway".  I have explained in detail to him the percentage risk of recurrance and I did ask him once, very casually "Do you have any questions about what I went through?" But none of that led any further than him telling me he loves me and will be here no matter what. I'm not complaining, but I just feel like there's this one thing hanging between us that makes me feel uncomfortable for a rare second or two. For example, jumping when his hand gets near radiated-tender boob, or I noticed today he looked away when I change shirts (could totally be paranoia on my part). He's obviously been great in every other way. Do I wait for him to say something or just tackle it head on and explain to him that it's a bit sore for now, explain the scars etc.... I'm usually so blunt, but for some reason I feel fearful to bring this up. I guess it's possible that I'll feel badly if he acts uncomfortable? Suggestions anyone? I think there's a thread like this regarding new boyfriend's, but this is a unique situation (new old boyfriend) and I trust your girls. Okay..phew..thanks for all your time. Happy Memorial Day and I love you all!

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2007 02:01PM Miss_Lolli wrote: Coach, sorry it took awhile for me to post but I heard something about concord grape juice bringing up blood counts. It sounds really simple, and I have no clue if it actually works, but I've heard it more than once and I guess there's no harm in trying either way. Evy, glad you're home and the surgery went well. You're in my thoughts often. Deb and Kristina, I'm so very sad that you're having such a hard time...I'm keeping you in my prayers and adding Vince..how tragic. I just wanted to take the time to say something in case anyone ends up having the same problem I did, it won't come as such a surprise and maybe make things easier for someone....When I was done with chemo (Nov. 30th) I expected to feel nothing but celebratory. I had these big ideas about outings and happiness and energy. LOL Well, I have to say that for some reason, and I'm still not sure why, I sunk into the deepest depression I've had since this whole ride started. I could barely get out of bed each day, and when I did I felt like there was no point in doing it. It took me over a week to realize that these weren't "true" feelings, but just sheer exhaustion, fatigue, maybe a little bit of a let down after trying so hard to tough it through chemo. Maybe a bit of isolation/feeling unneeded...not totally sure.  I'm wondering if I had some ridiculous notion that the moment they pulled that last IV outta me I would be "done" and everything would just fall into place. I would be immediately grateful and feel like I won a battle. And even more ridiculous I think I almost expected my energy to be back and my life to be close to what it was before. Mind you, I know this doesn't make sense and technically I knew better, but I just wanted to warn you girls for when your "no mo chemo" time comes. You may think that you'll feel like celebrating, but please don't be discouraged and scared if you don't. If I can save one person from beating themselves up over not just feeling grateful and elated then it was worth all the typing. I had to spill my guts to my sis and have her give me the "you've been through a lot" speech and let me know it was okay to be sad, scared, and depressed, along with my relief at being done. It's not totally gone, but I'm just trying to let myself have my feelings. It's hard, when you know some have it so much worse, to not kick yourself for having a pity party, but every little once in awhile, it's okay to mourn what we've lost too. I truly believe that. I just try not to wallow in it too much. lol Thanks for letting me ramble. I love you guys and hope you're well.

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2007 05:50PM Miss_Lolli wrote: Welcome NFlood. Too bad we couldn't meet under better circumstances. I can say that my weight has stayed pretty stable. The week after tx food tasted like cardboard, so I had very few things I cared to eat and lost weight. Second week was a celebration of that fact that I could taste again, and I'd pretty much gain what I'd lost.  So...except for the original ten I lost between dx and surgery (which I wanted to lose anyway) it was all a wash. I truly don't think chemo weight would stay, as Karen said, it's steroids and water weight mostly. I think that most of us found that we were so picky during chemo that it was more a matter of what our body would allow us to eat, rather than what we chose to eat. Seems that most pretty much eat either what doesn't taste funny, or one of the few things that sounds good. Be prepared to enjoy, and maybe even crave some foods you wouldn't previously consider and vice-versa. The hardest thing for me was steering clear of fresh fruits and veggies (nothing you can't either cook or peel). It's hard for me to eat healthy when I can't have my greens. I will say this...I wish I had gotten a rebounder to use indoors while it's below freezing....I just can't handle that weather. I think I would have lost if not for so much inactivity. Besides which, bouncing is so very good for cell rejuvination, and boosts your immune system, and gets your lymph fluids going. These all sound like good things for those with our dx, so I'm going to splurge on one after Christmas. Excuse the babbling...it happens to the extreme when I'm over-tired. lol If I'm not back before hand, hope those of you that celebrate have a wonderful and lovely holiday with lots of love and family. I love you sweeties.

You have a lot of love and support from your husband. We all need to find a bright spot and concentrate on that when we feel down. One thing I would suggest in dealing with your situation is to look at it this way....you don't have cancer, you HAD cancer. They removed it through surgery, and now you're having PREVENTATIVE treatment so it won't come back. With each day you are getting closer to your old healthy self. I know we all feel more vulnerable now with this diagnosis and fear of recurrance, but I'm trying so very hard to think of myself as recovering instead of a patient. Not so easy with a bald head, but it'll come back. Just think how cute you'll look with your short spiky new "do".  Also, as others have suggested, you need to talk to somebody about getting on some anti-depressants, or if you are taking some they need to be adjusted. You should not have to go on feeling stuck in such a dark place. Cheryl, hope that icky goo is gone soon. Those days where it's dark before you can even get home from work are such a bummer. We don't have many days with sunshine for about four or five months here in Minnesota either. If tanning booths were healthy I'd be there every day. lol Linda, great advice....we all need to be kind to ourselves. Kristina??? Sure would love to hear from you. Love and hugs to everyone...

Usually it's not the one big thing, but the tons of little things that get to you. I can relate to so much of what you expressed. I never even had to remind to straight A daughter to do her homework in her entire life. With my son it was a constant struggle. I not only had to tell him but stand over him and make sure it got done. He did get horrible grades and would tell me he didn't have homework when he had tons! Thank God he even graduated, but I think it was more work for me than him. lol  I never understood it, because he's actually very smart. I think he could've aced school with very little effort, but he put in less than that. I wish I had some words of wisdom for you there, but I never really found a good solution. As far as hubby, I'm sorry he's having to work so much. Hopefully the drinking thing is just a phase. I know that, even though I don't, I feel like drinking more often these days. Like it's an escape from my worries and what I've been through. If it wasn't so bad for my health I might imbibe more than I do. And I think when someone you love is sick it's even more stressful and much harder than when it's you (at least that's how I felt when my sis fell so ill over winter). So....I guess I wouldn't put up with more than what your tolerance level is, but I hope as things get closer to normal dh will feel more in control, and less like drinking. But like you said, what would that accomplish? Maybe it doesn't bother her, or maybe she'll learn to put her foot down. I know my family disliked my husband at first, but he grew a lot over the years, and they began to see that underneath it all is a good person with a good heart. 15 years post-divorce he's still invited to all family events that include my kids. I digress, but what I'm saying is....he may have a lot of growing up to do, and he may grow on you. It's just wonderful of you to support your daughter regardless. Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 10:38PM Miss_Lolli wrote: Worried Hubby...well I just look at it this way. If the risk of me developing leukemia, or some other major complication is 2% and the chemo only ups my survival rate by 1%, I would probably go with the odds. That said, I sure would never want to steer anyone in this either way. It's still a hard decision...fighting against something you have had, versus avoiding something you MIGHT have. I used to feel sorry that I had to have chemo, but now realize it's probably good that I didn't have to make a decision. Anyway, I'm sorry I probably haven't been much help, but I mostly wanted to say that your wife is not a statistic. She has to do what she feels is right for herself and then stick by that decision. Not second-guess herself or live with regrets. I hope you come to a decision and have peace with it very soon. Keep us posted if you can.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2008 09:47PM Miss_Lolli wrote: I had four dd AC w/o a port. I did have a problem only once, I hadn't drank enough water previous to my third tx and it was tough to get a vein when you're not hydrated (your veins contract when you're dehydrated). I can say that it ended up taking EIGHT tries that time, and it was miserable! I know it is a risk regarding the adriamycin missing a vein, it just needs to be monitored VERY closely at the start of infusion. I can't say whether it will cause problems in the future for my veins in my only available arm, I have had only one blood draw since. I've never had great veins, but my advice if you go for it....TONS of water the previous day and a hot towel or running your arm under very warm water for a few minutes before your infusion. My onc nurse didn't even mention a port, and when I asked she said she wouldn't bother with just four infusions...but she was quite good with the needle.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2008 04:25PM Miss_Lolli wrote: Thanks for the reminder Mar, I need to get some camisoles. Wow Paxton! I didn't know they'd even DO a lumpectomy w/o putting you out. I'm with you though, I'd rather not be put under, makes me feel too crappy after. I've had quite a few surgical things done while heavily sedated and I either just talk or sleep right through it. I figure I'm such a lightweight they can give me enough drugs to do practically anything while I'm awake and I'll be just fine with it. lol  Sorry to hear you're feeling bad, hope you bounce back very quickly. Abbi....after chemo the tats are for sure nothing. I likened mine to feeling like a mosquito bite. You're so right, the unknown is the WORST and I laugh at myself now that I was even nervous about rads. The possible se's, yeah that makes sense, but the actual zapping...it's nothing! roxy, I wish I had advice on how to "get through this" crapola. I just started and have no probs yet, so I'm really no help. All I know is, when I hear the the radiation machine working, I visualize healing rays beaming onto me. You can't really see or feel anything, but it just makes the slight buzzing noise seem friendlier. lol Other than that I just keep putting on my gel three times a day. For anyone who's nervous, I'll tell you exactly how my sessions go. I go into the room and get behind a curtained area to trade my shirt for a gown. I lay on a table and they put a cushion under my knees and take about ten seconds to make sure my tatts are lined up right (that's the only time they have to pull down the gown, which this freeze-baby was worried about lol).  They then leave the room, the machine buzzes for about ten seconds, slowly moves to the other side of my body for another ten seconds, and I'm done! There is nothing claustraphobic about it. From the time I lay down until the time I get up is less than a minute! I don't even have time to relax...sheesh.  I know once a week they take an xray to make sure everything is still lined up correctly...I imagine that will add another minute or so on there. Enjoy your weekend everyone!

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2008 09:33PM Miss_Lolli wrote: Well..I can say that my first rad session today was a "non-event". Actually when they left the room for a minute and came back and said ...okay you can sit up...I was like "WAH?" I thought they were still lining me up and didn't even realize that was my first session! Talk about anit-climactic. LOL  I know the whole thing will get old, and I'm sure I'll have some side effects, but how nice to have a tx where I don't have to worry about vomitting for the next week. Remind me of that statement in a month will ya? Hey chemomom, I'm sure they know what they're doing. Maybe the angle you get your chemo at won't "nick" your lungs and ribs like most do. To be sure I'd ask the rad onc. though and not just the tech who's zapping you. They may tell you that it's a possibility but not a sure thing for every one. I'm guessing the people who give you your radiation may not know as much about the se's as the doctor who should be the one to verify all possible effects with you. Although it seems the rad docs sometimes blame everything on chemo, and the oncs blame everything on rads. LOL As far as the creams....some places suggest applying from the beginning while some say wait until you have signs of damage (maybe they think it's better for your breast to be kept dry?). I don't think either way would harm you, but I think no matter which way you do it, from what I've read on these boards and my literature, you shouldn't put ANY creams, deodorants, lotions, etc. on in the morning before you have your radiation. I'm not sure, but I think when I put my lotion on this afternoon, my "lady lump" felt warm. Then again, I had just gotten home and it's freeeezing...so my hand could have just been cold too. lol Take care girls!

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2008 01:31PM - edited Apr 6, 2008 01:40PM by Miss_Lolli Well, I'm not as well-researched on the subject as I am on bc (of course), but I just went and did some reading. First off I noticed that with the dry scaly symptom you described the info says those spots are usually found on the limbs if they're something to worry about. The other thing, it didn't say anything about itching. So of course I think we should just automatically assume it's "nothing". BUT even if it were to be "something", it wouldn't be the most serious type of something and would be easily treatable (according to mayo clinic). I've never had a biopsy, but I know I've had mysterious skin things before...some never solved, but almost always things that turned out to be involved in stress. Most importantly, I think if your doc was leaning towards thinking it was skin cancer he would not be waiting to biopsy. Don't feel silly worrying about your tattoo. Those things are expensive, and usually a lot of thought and part of who you are goes into them. If I had one I know I'd be emotionally attached to it. Next step, get in there and get it biopsied so you can quit worrying. You have enough on your plate and no time for distractions sister! I'll pm you my number just in case you need to talk as well as type. Otherwise, please keep posting, keep us informed and let us be here for you.

Posts.Content: Miss_Lolli wrote: I had my very first visit today at an LE clinic, located in the hospital where I finished my rads last week. This was a strictly preventative measure and I thought the specialist seemed great. She measured, showed me how to keep my AND scar tissue soft with massage, gave me a lot of info, printed out some position papers for me, and told me about all of the things I could do to protect myself (which I mostly knew thanks to you lovely ladies), thank you!  She just seemed so informed and intelligent. My question is this....I have some 10 to 15 pound items I need to lift about five times a day at my job. I told her I planned to learn to do this lifting with my non-surgery arm. She told me that another option would be to wear a sleeve at work WITHOUT the glove. That just doesn't seem right to me. Haven't I heard somewhere that it is worse to do that than wearing no compression garments?  Just because I don't have symptoms doesn't mean I want to be careless about it. Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2007 09:19PM Miss_Lolli wrote: OMG....I just noticed you girls talking about the price of Emend. I have to tell you, I was off work at the time of my chemo, and a single mom to boot...Most insurance plans don't cover this drug because it's newer and not available in generic form. Well the wonderful drug company has a program and will send you Emend free if there is financial need! Just go to the Emend website and look for info on the "ACT program". The best thing.....not a ton of paperwork, just a paper for your onc to sign saying how many treatments you need it for, and one for you to sign and date. It was a God send as I would have spent 1400 dollars out of pocket for that one drug alone! Good luck with your tx's and feel free to drop into the October thread should you have any questions. Lotsa smart and empathetic ladies over there.
